0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• patients at higher risk for glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency (eg, patients of African or Mediterranean ancestry) should be screened prior to starting rasburicase because of the increased risk for severe hemolysis in these patients
  • Hyperuricemia, Due to malignancy, in patients receiving anticancer therapy expected to result in tumor lysis syndrome: Multidose weight-based therapy, 0.2 mg/kg IV infusion over 30 minutes once daily for up to 5 days; administration beyond 5 days or 1 course of treatment is not recommended (manufacturer dose)
  • Hyperuricemia, Due to malignancy, in patients receiving anticancer therapy expected to result in tumor lysis syndrome: Single-dose weight-based therapy, 0.15 mg/kg IV over 30 minutes at least 4 hours and no more than 24 hours before initiation of chemotherapy on day 1; repeated if plasma uric acid levels exceed 7.5 mg/dL; MAX 5 doses (study dose)
  • Hyperuricemia, Due to malignancy, in patients receiving anticancer therapy expected to result in tumor lysis syndrome: Single-dose fixed therapy, 3 or 6 mg IV once in addition to oral allopurinol, adequate hydration, and other supportive case as necessary (study dose).

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• patients at higher risk for glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency (eg, patients of African or Mediterranean ancestry) should be screened prior to starting rasburicase because of the increased risk for severe hemolysis in these patients
  • Hyperuricemia, Due to malignancy, in patients receiving anticancer therapy expected to result in tumor lysis syndrome: (1 month or older) 0.2 mg/kg IV infusion over 30 minutes once daily for up to 5 days; administration beyond 5 days or 1 course of treatment is not recommended

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Hyperuricemia, Due to malignancy, in patients receiving anticancer therapy expected to result in tumor lysis syndrome

2.title: Black Box Warning
2.mono:
Intravenous (Powder for Solution)
Rasburicase may cause severe hypersensitivity reactions including anaphylaxis, hemolysis in patients with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency, and methemoglobinemia. Therapy should be immediately and permanently discontinued in any patient developing these conditions. Rasburicase will cause enzymatic degradation of the uric acid within blood samples left at room temperature, resulting in spuriously low uric acid levels.

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency; may cause severe hemolysis
  • hemolytic reactions to rasburicase or any of its excipients, history of
  • hypersensitivity reactions, including anaphylaxis, to rasburicase or any of its excipients, history of
  • methemoglobinemia reactions to rasburicase or any of its excipients, history of

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• anaphylaxis has occurred
  • hemolysis, severe has occurred in patients with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency
  • methemoglobinemia, serious has occurred

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Rash (13%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Abdominal pain (20%), Constipation (20%), Diarrhea (20%), Inflammatory disease of mucous membrane (15%), Nausea (27%), Vomiting (50%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (26%)
  • Other:Fever (46%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Cardiac arrest (1% or less), Cardiac dysrhythmia (1% or less), Chest pain (1% or less), Cyanosis (1% or less), Heart failure (1% or less), Myocardial infarction (1% or less)
  • Dermatologic:Cellulitis (1% or less), Rash, Serious (1%)
  • Endocrine metabolic:Dehydration (1% or less)
  • Gastrointestinal:Bowel obstruction (1% or less), Diarrhea, Serious (1% or less), Inflammatory disease of mucous membrane, Serious (2%)
  • Hematologic:Febrile neutropenia (4%), Hemolysis (less than 1%), Hemorrhage (1% or less), Methemoglobinemia (less than 1%), Neutropenia (2%), Pancytopenia (1% or less), Thrombophlebitis (1% or less), Thrombosis (1% or less)
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis (less than 1%), Hypersensitivity reaction, Infectious disease (1% or less), Sepsis (3%)
  • Neurologic:Cerebrovascular disease (1% or less), Paresthesia (1% or less)
  • Ophthalmic:Retinal hemorrhage (1% or less)
  • Renal:Acute renal failure (1% or less)
  • Respiratory:Pneumonia (1% or less), Pulmonary edema (1% or less), Pulmonary hypertension (1% or less), Respiratory distress (3%)
  • Other:Fever, Serious (5%), Menopausal flushing (1% or less), Rigor (1% or less)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Systemic: Uric acid is the final step in the catabolic pathway of purines. Rasburicase catalyzes oxidation of uric acid into an inactive and soluble metabolite (allantoin). Hydrogen peroxide is one of the major by-products of this conversion. Rasburicase is only active at the end of the purine catabolic pathway..

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • reconstitute using supplied diluent and swirl very gently; do not shake or vortex; may store reconstituted or diluted solution up to 24 hours at 2 to 8 degrees C; discard if particulates are visible or if discolored
  • dilute in NS to a final volume of 50 mL; may store up to 24 hours at 2 to 8 degrees C; discard unused portion
  • administer by IV infusion over 30 minutes; do not administer as bolus infusion
  • infuse through a separate line when possible, otherwise flush before and after infusion with at least 15 mL of saline; do not filter

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• plasma uric acid levels
  • tumor lysis syndrome evaluation (eg, serum creatinine and electrolytes)
  • screening for patients at a higher risk for glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency; prior to starting rasburicase
  • signs and symptoms of a severe allergic reaction

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
RASBURICASE
OVERDOSE - No cases of overdose have been reported with rasburicase. Based on the mechanism of action, an overdose will lead to undetectable or low plasma uric acid concentrations which has no known clinical consequences. Extensions of adverse effects such as methemoglobinemia or hemolysis may occur. ADVERSE EVENTS: SERIOUS - Hypersensitivity reactions including anaphylaxis, severe hemolysis in patients with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency and methemoglobinemia have been reported with use. Other events include neutropenia, febrile neutropenia, respiratory distress and sepsis. Many of the reported adverse effects are likely secondary to concomitant chemotherapy that was administered. COMMON - Events frequently reported regardless of severity include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, abdominal pain, mucositis, fever, headache and rash. SERIOUS/UNCOMMON - Acute renal failure, cardiac arrest, arrhythmia, myocardial infarction, cellulitis, cerebrovascular disorder, seizures, chest pain, cyanosis, dehydration, hot flushes, ileus, intestinal obstruction, infection, paresthesia, pancytopenia, pneumonia, pulmonary edema, pulmonary hypertension, retinal hemorrhage, rigors, thrombosis and thrombophlebitis have occurred.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
RASBURICASE
  • Decontamination: Administered intravenously; ingestion is unlikely.
  • Methemoglobinemia: Administer high flow oxygen. Methylene blue 1 to 2 mg/kg intravenously over 5 minutes in patients with significant symptoms (symptoms usually occur with methemoglobin levels greater than 20% to 30%, may occur at lower levels in patients with anemia, pulmonary or cardiovascular disease. Exchange transfusion has been used in patients unresponsive to methylene blue. Hyperbaric oxygen may be adjunctive therapy in severe cases.
  • Seizure: IV benzodiazepines, barbiturates.
  • Support: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive. Supportive antiemetic and antidiarrheal agents may be indicated to manage symptoms.
  • Myelosuppression: Severe neutropenia: filgrastim 5 mcg/kg/day subcutaneously, or sargramostim 250 mcg/m(2)/day infused over 4 hours.
  • Intrathecal injection: No clinical reports of intrathecal injection of rasburicase are available. This information was derived from experience with other antineoplastics. Keep the patient upright if possible. Immediately drain at least 20 mL CSF; drainage of up to 70 mL has been tolerated in adults. Follow with CSF exchange (remove serial 20 mL aliquots CSF and replace with equivalent volumes of warmed, preservative-free normal saline or lactated ringers). Consult a neurosurgeon for placement of a ventricular catheter and begin ventriculolumbar perfusion (infuse warmed preservative-free NS or LR through ventricular catheter, drain fluid from lumbar catheter; typical volumes are 80 to 150 mL/hr for 18 to 24 hours). Dexamethasone 4 mg IV every 6 hours to prevent arachnoiditis.
  • Monitoring of patient: Monitor serial CBCs with differential and platelet counts following exposure. If the patient is cyanotic, obtain hemoglobin and methemoglobin levels. Monitor fluid and electrolytes in patients with signs and symptoms of fluid imbalance. Monitor serum uric acid levels (must be drawn into pre-chilled heparinized tubes and maintained in an ice water bath and assayed within 4 hours to be accurate).

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
RASBURICASE
TOXICITY: No cases of overdose have been reported with rasburicase. Maximum dose administered as a single dose is 0.20 mg/kg. Maximum daily dose administered is 0.40 mg/kg. ADULT THERAPEUTIC DOSING: The recommended dose is 0.15 or 0.20 mg/kg as a single daily dose for 5 days. Dosing beyond 5 days or administration of more than one course of rasburicase is not recommended. Chemotherapy should be started 4 to 24 hours after the first dose of rasburicase. Rasburicase should be administered as an IV infusion over 30 minutes and not as a bolus infusion.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Drug may cause rash, abdominal pain, constipation, diarrhea, headache, mucositis, nausea, vomiting, and fever.
  • Instruct patient or caregiver to report signs/symptoms of methemoglobinemia (respiratory distress, cyanosis) or hemolysis (shortness of breath, rapid heart rate, jaundice).
